etymologies: 1970s; earliest use found in The Boston Globe. Apparently from Cuban Spanish songo (although this is apparently first attested later: 1990 or earlier) from son + -go

definitions: A genre of Cuban music incorporating traditional rumba elements into popular dance music, influenced by rock, jazz, and Brazilian music. Also (and in earliest use): the distinctive syncopated rhythm which characterizes this genre.

notes.text: Frequently attributive, as "songo beat", "songo rhythm," etc.
